instruction:
A job description is a document that clearly states the requirements, duties, responsibilities, and skills required to perform a specific role. You need to write a job description based on the given information. You should describe responsibilities and duties in your job description in a logical order. Remember that potential employees often get their first impression of your company from your job description. So, the job description should convey the attractiveness of your company.

Company: [Company name]
Job: Software Engineer
Job Responsibilities:
Receive and perform code reviews with other engineers.
Write unit, integration, and end-to-end tests to verify functionality using automated testing frameworks such as Pytest.
Work collaboratively with fellow software engineers to build features requested by business stakeholders.
Participate in Agile teams to develop, test, and debug complex data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark.
Diagnose, debug, and perform root cause analysis of issues and defects.
Skills and experience that will lead to success:
Experience with a modern software programming language. We use Python, and Pyspark extensively.
Experience with cloud systems like AWS or Azure
Experience writing SQL queries 
Strong written and verbal communication skills
Eagerness to work in a highly-collaborative environment
Some visualization experience such as Tableau or PowerBI is helpful
output:
The Software Engineer at our esteemed organization shall be responsible for executing various tasks aimed at delivering quality solutions for our clients' diverse needs. The key job functions include receiving and assessing submitted codes alongside fellow developers, implementing unit, integration, and end-to-end tests leveraging automation tools such as PyTest to confirm product efficacy. Collaborating seamlessly with other engineers, this professional will contribute to building innovative functionalities per stakeholder requests within an agile team structure. Furthermore, they shall participate actively in developing sophisticated data processing streams via Big Data processing platforms including Apache Spark, while also performing detailed fault diagnosis and remediation procedures.

Our ideal candidate must boast relevant practical knowledge and proficiency in contemporary programming languages like Python and PySpark. They must have prior experiences working with popular cloud computing ecosystems such as Amazon Web Services (AWS) or Microsoft Azure. Additionally, candidates with ample background in constructing structured SQL statements are strongly preferred. Other essential qualities comprise exceptional interpersonal abilities in both oral and written communication channels, plus a demonstrated enthusiasm to foster cooperative environments among colleagues. Lastly, attaining familiarity with renowned visualization tools like Tableau or Power BI would significantly enhance one’s prospects of succeeding in this position.

Main point of the section: jeans can be worn all year and look good with everything .
output:
Trusty Jeans - A Classic Staple for Every Traveler's Wardrobe

Jeans never go out of style, making them an essential item for any traveler’s wardrobe. They offer comfort, versatility, and practicality that is hard to beat when embarking on a journey. Whether you prefer classic denim or trendy washes, these trustworthy pants come in various styles that cater to different tastes and occasions.

One of the main reasons why jeans are perfect for traveling is their ability to pair well with almost anything. You can dress them up with elegant blouses or dresses or keep it casual with graphic tees and sweaters. Their neutral tones also make them effortlessly chic when combined with bold accessories like statement jewelry, belts, or scarves. Moreover, jeans work equally well with boots, sneakers, sandals, and heels, ensuring that they match your footwear choices as well.

Another advantage of wearing jeans while traveling is their durability and ease of maintenance. Jeans resist wrinkles, tears, and stains, making them resilient against everyday wear and tear. Additionally, since they do not require special care instructions, washing them becomes hassle-free, saving time and water during your trip. Simply toss them into the laundry bag and let the hotel staff handle the rest.

In summary, jeans should undoubtedly occupy a prominent place in every traveler's luggage due to their timeless appeal, versatility, and functionality. With so many stylish options available in the market, investing in a quality pair of jeans will elevate your travel fashion game without compromising on comfort and practicality. So pack those denims confidently, knowing that they will serve you well no matter where life takes you!

instruction:
Find synonyms for the given word. You need to write down how the provided synonyms differ from the original word in terms of meaning, usage, etc.

adversity
output: Synonyms: hardship, difficulty, challenge, adverseness, struggle, affliction, tribulation, trial. Adversity differs from these words in that it suggests a significant and challenging obstacle or setback which must be overcome through perseverance, strength, and resilience. Difficulty implies a more general sense of difficulty, while challenge emphasizes the opportunity for growth and development through overcoming obstacles. Struggle may suggest greater emotional turmoil, whereas affliction highlights external sources of suffering. Tribulation refers specifically to extreme trials, while trial signifies a formal examination or test of one's abilities or character. Overall, adversity carries with it connotations of endurance and determination despite overwhelming odds.

instruction:
Discuss the origins and history of the word that has been given to you.

oblique
output:
The origin of the term "oblique" can be traced back to Middle English in the late 13th century, derived from the Old French adjective "obliques." The word comes from the Latin "obliquus," meaning inclined or slanted. It was used to describe objects or actions that were tilted or not straight. Over time, it also came to mean indirect or off-course in language, thought, or action.

Throughout its history, "oblique" has been used as an important concept in fields such as mathematics, art, literature, and philosophy. In geometry, for example, oblique lines do not intersect at right angles but instead form a diagonal intersection point. In painting and sculpture, artists have employed oblique perspectives and foreshortening techniques to create more dynamic compositions with depth and movement.

In literary contexts, writers often use "oblique" language or allusions to suggest multiple interpretations or deeper underlying meanings beyond literal textual representations. Philosophically, oblique thinking may involve considering alternative viewpoints or finding subtle connections between seemingly unrelated concepts. Overall, the idea of being "oblique" continues to intrigue people across various disciplines because of its ability to offer new insights into complex phenomena through novel approaches.

instruction: Write a step-by-step guide for resolving GitHub merge conflicts.
output:
Here is a step-by-step guide to resolve GitHub merge conflicts:

1. Pull the latest changes from remote branch: Firstly, ensure that you have pulled the most recent commits and updates of your repository by running `git pull` command in your terminal or Git client.

2. Checkout the conflicted branch: After pulling the newest commit, check out the conflicting branch using the `checkout` command with its corresponding name. You can identify the branch through the ‘conflict’ message displayed during the `pull` process.

3. Resolve merge conflicts locally: Merge conflicts occur when multiple contributors make modifications on the same lines within files concurrently. To solve this problem, open the specific file(s) containing conflicts in your preferred text editor, and examine the marked areas highlighting discrepancies between local and remote versions. Make changes to the code as required, then save your modified content.

4. Use the diff tool for more complex merges: For large or intricate mergers involving many files and directories, it might be easier to utilize tools like Beyond Compare or Visual Studio Code's built-in Diff feature to pinpoint the sections where alterations took place across different branches.

5. Stage changed files: Once modifying the conflicting files, use the command `git add <file/folder>` to stage them before committing any updates into the new merge commit. Ensure all staged changes are correctly aligned with the updated contents after editing.

6. Commit the resolved changes: Submit the newly merged changes via the `commit -m "Resolved merge conflict"`, providing an informative description of what was altered or rectified. This action saves the present state of your local version history.

7. Push changes upstream: Finally, push the latest changes to the desired remote branch utilizing the command `git push origin <branch_name>`.

8. Review and verify merge status: Examine the dashboard or view logs to confirm the success of the merge operation. Verify that there aren't any unresolved disputes remaining between diverging versions of a particular project. If necessary, revert back previous steps to fix any overlooked issues.

That's it! With these simple steps, you should be able to efficiently resolve merge conflicts while working collaboratively on projects hosted on GitHub.

instruction:
One or more jobs can be run automatically by a workflow. The workflows are defined in the repository as YAML files and will run if an event occurs in the repository, as well as manually, or on a certain schedule.
Bring an example of a workflow that demonstrate the CI/CD features of GitHub Actions.
output:
Here's an example of a workflow configuration file for implementing Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Deployment (CD) using GitHub Actions:

```yaml
name: CI/CD Workflow
on: push
jobs:
  build-and-test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout Repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Build with Node.js
        uses: actions/setup-node@v1
        with:
          node-version: '14.x'

      - name: Install Dependencies
        run: npm install

      - name: Run Tests
        run: npm test

  deploy-to-production:
    needs: build-and-test
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Deploy to Production Server
        run: ssh user@server "bash scripts/deploy.sh"
```

This workflow has two jobs: `build-and-test` and `deploy-to-production`. When pushed to the main branch, it triggers the `build-and-test` job, which checks out the codebase, sets up Node.js environment, installs dependencies, and executes tests. If these steps pass, then the subsequent deployment job is triggered with the `needs: build-and-test` property, indicating that this step depends on successful completion of previous tasks. 

The deployment job connects via SSH to production server and invokes a bash script named `deploy.sh`, making changes live. This configuration allows for fast and reliable builds, testing, and streamlined deployment processes without manual intervention. With the help of GitHub Actions, you can automate your software development lifecycle from commits to releases and achieve better productivity.

instruction: Name the top cities in France that should not be missed. Include the best aspects of each place as well.

1. Paris - Known for its iconic Eiffel Tower and stunning architecture, Paris also boasts world-class museums like the Louvre, exquisite cuisine, lively nightlife, charming cafes, and romantic strolls along the Seine River.

2. Provence - Famous for its picturesque lavender fields, Provençal cuisine, historic medieval villages, breathtaking coastal scenery, beautiful vineyards, and warm climate make this region an unforgettable destination.

3. Lyon - The gastronomic capital of France offers mouthwatering dishes such as coq au vin and quenelles de brochet, alongside stunning Renaissance architecture, captivating art galleries, and impressive landmarks like Notre-Dame de Fourvière Basilica.

4. Nice - With its Mediterranean charm, palm trees lined streets, and glittering beaches, Nice is a paradise for beach lovers. It's famous for its vibrant markets, scenic Promenade des Anglais walkway, exceptional food, luxurious hotels, and elegant boutiques.

5. Bordeaux - As one of the most significant wine regions globally, Bordeaux is home to some of the finest vineyards and wineries, where visitors can sample the area's famous red wines, take guided tours through ancient cellars or explore stylish neighborhoods, excellent restaurants, and magnificent architecture.

6. Marseille - This port city bursts with character, from bustling street scenes filled with colorful buildings, fabulous seafood delights, exciting historical sites like Fort Saint Jean, and unique art forms like graffiti murals and street performances.

7. Avignon - Renowned for its papal history, Avignon features enchanting Gothic churches, fortified walls encircled by the Rhone river, fantastic art collections at Calvet Museum, and delicious local dishes.

8. Toulouse - A thriving student town, Toulouse has an upbeat atmosphere, rich cultural heritage showcased in museums, architectural marvels including St Sernin Basilica, delightful markets, and modern amenities catering to young travelers.

9. Nantes - Home to incredible sculptures by artist François Pompon scattered across the city, Nantes hosts a wide range of attractions such as Machines of the Isle of Nantes, Jules Verne’s birthplace, remarkable botanical gardens, and mouthwatering Creperie specialties.

10. Lille - Known for its delightful Victorian architecture, enchanting Christmas Markets, trendy designer boutiques, popular festivals, and mouthwatering culinary scene featuring Belgian, French, and European cuisines, Lille offers plenty of reasons why it deserves a spot on any must-visit list.

instruction:
You are given two questions. Check if they are duplicates.

Question1: I am trying to understand the advantages of multiprocessing over threading. I know that multiprocessing gets around the Global Interpreter Lock, but what other advantages are there, and can threading not do the same thing?
Question2: I am learning how to use the threading and the multiprocessing modules in Python to run certain operations in parallel and speed up my code.
I am finding this hard (maybe because I don't have any theoretical background about it) to understand what the difference is between a threading.Thread() object and a multiprocessing.Process() one.
Also, it is not entirely clear to me how to instantiate a queue of jobs and having only 4 (for example) of them running in parallel, while the other wait for resources to free before being executed.
I find the examples in the documentation clear, but not very exhaustive; as soon as I try to complicate things a bit, I receive a lot of weird errors (like a method that can't be pickled, and so on).
So, when should I use the threading and multiprocessing modules?
Can you link me to some resources that explain the concepts behind these two modules and how to use them properly for complex tasks?
output:
Questions 1 and 2 appear to be related. In question 1, you ask about the advantages of multiprocessing versus threading. Multiprocessing allows multiple processes to execute independently with their own memory space, which eliminates issues caused by the GIL. Additionally, multiprocessing can take advantage of multi-core CPUs more effectively than threading since threads share memory, leading to potential contention. Threading may also lead to deadlocks due to shared memory access conflicts. On the other hand, threading can provide better performance for single-threaded CPU bound workloads, like I/O or network communication, where context switching overhead is lower compared to creating new process instances.

In question 2, you seek guidance on using threading and multiprocessing modules for more advanced tasks. To learn about the underlying principles of these modules, you could refer to official Python documentation, tutorials, and books such as "Python Concurrency Cookbook" by Luis Lavena or "Python Multi-Processing and Parallelism". Additionally, online communities, including Stack Overflow, provide valuable insights into common challenges and solutions for multithreading and multiprocessing applications. When deciding whether to employ threading or multiprocessing, consider factors such as task granularity, resource availability, application architecture, and programming style preferences. A general rule of thumb is that threading might perform well for small tasks that require frequent synchronization among workers, whereas multiprocessing would excel at scaling large data sets across multiple cores. Ultimately, understanding the strengths and limitations of each approach will help optimize your code for maximum efficiency and reliability.

instruction:
Design a programming problem related to the subject that has been given to you. Use some examples and constraints to improve your question.

Dynamic Programming
output:
Problem: Longest Common Subsequence (LCS) in Strings using Dynamic Programming

Given two strings str1 and str2 of length n and m respectively, find their longest common subsequence i.e., the longest sequence present in both the strings. The LCS can be defined as the longest sequence of characters which is common in both the input strings and appears in the same order.

Example:
str1 = "AGGTAB"
str2 = "GXTXAYB"
Output: LCS(str1, str2) = 4
Explanation: The LCS between these two strings is 'GXTXA'.

Constraints:
- Both str1 and str2 should contain only lowercase letters.
- The inputs provided will always have an LCS with a positive length.
- The solution must use dynamic programming approach for optimal time complexity.

Approach: A bottom up dynamic programming algorithm could be used to solve this problem by building a table to store values of subproblems already solved. Initially, set all cells to 0 except cell at index (i=0, j=0), where LCS value would be initialized with 0. Then iterate through each character in both string starting from second position. For a particular pair of indices I and j, calculate LCS as LCS(str1[i], str2[j]) if they match or else take maximum of previous diagonal elements LCS(str1[i-1], str2[j]) and LCS(str1[i], str2[j-1]). Finally, return the value stored in last cell of table.

The space complexity is O(nm) and Time Complexity is O(n*m). This approach provides optimal solutions in linear time while traversing the strings once.

instruction:

An integer n is a power of three, if there exists an integer x such that n == 3^x.

In: n = 27
Out: true
Explanation: 27 = 3^3

Example 2:
In: n = 0
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3^x = 0.

Example 3:
In: n = -1
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3x = (-1).
 
Constraints:
-231 <= n <= 231 - 1
Follow up: Could you solve it without loops/recursion?

instruction:
You are given a programming problem and its implementation. Analyze the problem and implementation and explain the algorithm and approach used to solve the problem.

Table: Person
| Column Name | Type     |
| personId          | int         |
| lastName         | varchar |
| firstName         | varchar |
personId is the primary key column for this table.
This table contains information about the ID of some persons and their first and last names.
Table: Address
| Column Name | Type     |
| addressId        | int         |
| personId          | int         |
| city                   | varchar|
| state                | varchar |
addressId is the primary key column for this table.
Each row of this table contains information about the city and state of one person with ID = PersonId.
Write an SQL query to report the first name, last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table. If the address of a personId is not present in the Address table, report null instead.
Return the result table in any order.
Implementation:
select FirstName, LastName, City, State
from Person left join Address
on Person.PersonId = Address.PersonId
;
output:
The problem statement involves reporting the first name, last name, city, and state of each person from the Person table while also taking into consideration the absence or presence of corresponding addresses in the Address table. The solution proposed utilizes a LEFT JOIN between the two tables on the common PersonId column.

LEFT JOIN allows all records from the "left" (in our case, the Person) table to be returned, even if there's no matching record found in the other ("right", here Address) table. This makes it possible to handle cases where certain people might have missing or invalid addresses in the database by returning NULL values instead of actual cities/states.

In terms of algorithmic approach, we can break down the query as follows:
1. SELECT columns from both Person and Address tables - we want to retrieve FirstName, LastName, City, and State attributes.
2. Join the tables using the shared PersonId field - this will allow us to correlate data across multiple rows and ensure that each person has all relevant details associated with them.
3. Use a LEFT JOIN rather than INNER JOIN so that unmatched entries in either side do not get filtered out. In such cases, the corresponding fields in the right-side table would appear as NULL.
4. Order results in any fashion desired (optional step).

Thus, the provided implementation utilizing LEFT JOIN efficiently solves the stated challenge of retrieving complete but optional address information along with personal identifiers for every individual in the Person dataset.

instruction:
Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.

Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts.
Mathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:√2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht Dürer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting.
output: The interconnection between math and art is multifaceted. Math has been depicted as an artistic pursuit rooted in elegance. Visual arts including music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles exhibit mathematical concepts. Historically, artists employed math principles like Golden Ratio proportion for ideal human figure portrayals or implemented perspectives through Euclid’s theories. Famous figures like Leonardo da Vinci and Albrecht Durer showcased math influences within their works. Modern examples include geometrically oriented movements such as De Stijl and M.C. Escher's incorporations of hyperbolic patterns. Textile arts and Islamic designs also manifest symmetry applications.

instruction:

The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.
output: The fair trade movement, commonly referred to as the "trade justice" movement, emphasizes the implementation of socially responsible labor practices, sustainable environmental policies, and equitable social standards across various industries, notably those originating in developing countries that are traded with developed nations. The initiative aims to ensure producers receive just compensation for their efforts while supporting local communities' well-being through improved livelihood opportunities. These principles have prompted a contentious dialogue about whether global commerce can be acknowledged as an inherent human right. By advocating for transparency, accountability, and dignity throughout the supply chain, the fair trade approach serves to empower marginalized individuals and promote long-term economic development within impoverished regions worldwide.

Course Title: Programming for Everybody - Getting started with Python

Syllabus Outline:

Chapter 1: Introduction to Programming and Python
- Brief introduction to programming concepts such as variables, data types, control structures, functions, etc.
- An overview of Python’s features that make it an excellent choice for beginners in programming.
- Hands-on activities to understand basic coding techniques using Python.

Chapter 2: Data Types and Variables
- Explanation of different data types in Python including integers, floats, strings, booleans, lists, tuples, dictionaries, etc.
- Understanding variable assignments and scope.
- Practice exercises to write code for manipulating data types and working with variables.

Chapter 3: Control Structures
- Explaining if statements, loops, try-except blocks and their role in program execution.
- Code examples demonstrating how these control structures can be used to solve problems effectively.
- Interactive quizzes to test students' understanding of controlling program flow.

Chapter 4: Functions
- Introducing functions as reusable chunks of code.
- Discussing function arguments, local vs global variables, returning values from functions, and recursion.
- Practical tasks where students will create functions and use them to perform specific operations.

Chapter 5: Libraries & APIs
- Overview on popular libraries like NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, and Seaborn.
- Understanding Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) and learning how to access external resources through them.
- Project-based assignment that requires application of the knowledge gained by utilizing various Python libraries and API interfaces.

Chapter 6: Debugging Techniques
- Demystifying errors in programs and debugging methods.
- Incorporating tools like pdb or IDEs debugger into the workflow.
- Practicing identifying bugs and troubleshooting them step-by-step.

Chapter 7: Working with Files
- Dealing with files in Python, opening and reading/writing files.
- Handling exceptions related to file handling and exploring regular expressions.
- Workshop exercises covering file input/output and text processing using Python modules.

Assessment Methodologies: Quiz after every chapter, hands-on projects and a final project incorporating everything learned throughout the course. A mix of multiple-choice questions, problem solving tasks, and real world applications shall assess student comprehension. 

Overall Course Objective: To equip learners with fundamental knowledge and skills necessary to develop Python codes for practical purposes while improving critical thinking abilities via engaging practical tasks.

instruction:
List the personality traits that are required to be successful in the given job.

Social Media Marketer
output:
1. Creative: Social media marketers should have an imaginative mindset and think outside of the box to create engaging content for their social media channels.

2. Strategic thinking: They must possess strong analytical skills along with strategic planning abilities to devise efficient campaigns and achieve specific goals.

3. Communication Skills: Excellent verbal and written communication skills help them articulate effectively on various social platforms while building relationships with customers and clients.

4. Adaptability: With rapid technological advancements and ever-changing trends within digital marketing, adaptable personalities will thrive as they can pivot strategies quickly based on new data insights or emerging best practices.

5. Analytical Mindset: Social media marketers require proficiency in analyzing campaign performance metrics such as engagement rates, conversion rate optimization (CRO), and ROI calculations. This ability helps to optimize future campaigns continually.

6. Strong problem-solving capabilities: A vital trait for any Social Media Manager is having an excellent problem-solving skill set, making it easier to identify issues, implement solutions swiftly, and ultimately boost overall productivity.

7. Tech Savvy: Keeping up with current technology tools and staying abreast of industry developments is crucial since social media marketing heavily relies upon modern tech innovations like Artificial Intelligence(AI) & Machine Learning algorithms.

8. Attention To Detail: The role demands attention to detail, ensuring every piece of information shared online is accurate and error-free. Any minor oversight could lead to damaging brand reputation and result in loss of trust from followers.

9. Collaboration: Successful Social Media Marketers build strong working relationships with team members, including designers, copywriters, and developers, all collaborating towards achieving common objectives.

10. Passionate about Digital Marketing: Lastly, a genuine passion for social media and digital marketing drives an individual's commitment to continuously learning new techniques and tactics. Additionally, keeping themselves updated on emerging trends and adapting accordingly will keep them ahead of the curve.

instruction:
Create a daily itinerary based on the given information.

Our family is looking for a 9-day Morocco trip that has light to moderate activity levels.
output:
Day 1: Arrival in Marrakech and guided tour of historic sites such as Bahia Palace and Koutoubia Mosque. Afternoon free time for shopping at souks or exploring local markets. Evening dinner with traditional music performance.

Day 2: Drive through Atlas Mountains to Asilah and enjoy scenic views along the way. Visit the colorful seaside town and its historical fortified walls. Enjoy lunch by the sea before continuing to Chefchaouen, famous for blue buildings and vibrant culture. Explore old medina (old city) on foot in afternoon.

Day 3: Take an easy hike around Rif mountains near Chefchaouen for morning exercise followed by visit to a waterfall nearby. Have a picnic lunch while enjoying nature. Return back to Chefchaouen for more exploration. In the evening, attend a cooking class with a Moroccan chef.

Day 4: Head to Fes via Meknes and Volubilis, an ancient Roman ruins site. Upon arrival, take a walking tour of Fes Medina including visiting Al Attarine Madrasa, Bou Anania Madrasa and Dar Batha Museum. Try authentic tagines at night.

Day 5: Morning camel trek into desert landscape from Merzouga before arriving at Gourma oasis camp where tents are set up for overnight stay under starry sky. Experience traditional Bedouin lifestyle by attending storytelling sessions and watching traditional Berber music performances.

Day 6: Depart from Merzouga and drive southwards towards Todra Gorge which features towering red sandstone cliffs. Hiking opportunities await here. Spend the evening in Dades Valley amongst beautiful palm groves.

Day 7: A day spent entirely in Ouarzazate. Start early in the morning with a sunrise hot air balloon ride over valleys and canyons. Then discover the Kasbah of Taourit, Atlas Film Studio, and visit various museums. Stay the night.

Day 8: Make your way to Essaouira, once a Portuguese fishing port turned UNESCO World Heritage Site. Walk around the narrow streets lined with whitewashed houses and watch artisans create handmade crafts like pottery and embroideries. Also visit Sidi Mohammed Ben Abdallah Museum.

Day 9: Final stop will be in Marrakech. Leisurely explore the Jardin Majorelle Botanical Gardens, Saadian Tombs and Bahia Palace one last time. Transfer to airport for departure flight.

instruction: Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations.
output:
1. Practice: Practice your presentation several times before the actual day of the presentation. The more familiar you become with your material and delivery style, the more confident you will feel when presenting in front of an audience.

2. Visualize success: Picture yourself delivering a successful presentation, engaging with the audience, and receiving positive feedback. This visualization can help build confidence and reduce anxiety.

3. Take deep breaths: Deep breathing exercises can help calm nerves by reducing stress hormones and promoting relaxation. Before stepping up to speak, take some slow, deep breaths to help regulate your heart rate and relax your body.

4. Focus on the message: Instead of worrying about making mistakes or stumbling over words, focus on the content of your presentation. Remember why it is important and what key points you want to convey.

5. Connect with the audience: Make eye contact with individual members of the audience, smile, and use gestures to engage them. This connection helps create a friendly atmosphere that makes nervousness less intimidating.

6. Use positive self-talk: Remind yourself of your strengths and abilities. Encourage yourself with affirming phrases like "I am prepared," "I have valuable insights" or "I can do this!" Self-affirmation can help foster greater confidence and positivity.

7. Seek support: Consider reaching out for advice from teachers or mentors who may be able to provide insight into managing stage fright. Additionally, practice presentations in front of trusted friends, family or peers can also provide much-needed encouragement.

instruction: You can easily make your holidays more eco-friendly by following these simple steps:

5. Consider donating to charitable organizations or environmental causes in lieu of physical presents.
6. Use cloth napkins and dishes instead of disposable items when hosting festive gatherings.

10. Spread awareness about the importance of sustainability and eco-friendliness with family members and friends through thoughtful conversations.

E-waste is a huge problem. What can you make using old electronics and other salvageable electronic materials? 
We have a special judges prize for our favorite Instructable that incorporates or is related to reusing e-waste.
Be smart and be safe; note that potentially deadly projects (like Lichtenberg/fractal wood burning machines) will not be allowed to be published or submitted to this contest.
output:
Idea: Upcycled E-Waste Speaker

Steps:
1. Gather old electronic components such as circuit boards, speakers, wires, etc. From e-waste sources like discarded phones, laptops, and audio devices. Ensure safety measures when handling these components.
2. Clean and organize the collected parts. Remove any unnecessary hardware or connectors.
3. Design a speaker housing made from upcycled materials, such as cardboard boxes, wooden crates, or even paper mache. Cut out openings in the sides to fit the speaker components.
4. Wire the speaker driver(s) and amplifier together with salvaged wiring. Connect them to the power source via old DC adapters or batteries.
5. Add extra decorative elements to the speaker case using more repurposed items like metal scraps, buttons, broken jewelry, or paint. This step adds character and makes it unique.
6. Test the speaker's sound quality thoroughly before finalizing its design. Make adjustments if necessary.
7. Create instructions on how others could create their own upcycled e-waste speaker through clear photos and written descriptions. Submit the project to the contest and highlight the use of sustainable techniques.
8. Have fun creating something useful from waste while being mindful of environmental impact. Be sure to follow all proper precautions when working with electrical components.

instruction:
Provide a detailed explanation of the steps that are required in order to construct the given project.

Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can
output:
Constructing a steam engine using an empty beer can may seem challenging but with careful following of these steps, it is possible:

Materials Needed:
- An empty beer can (12 oz)
- A rubber band or elastic
- Thin wooden dowel or rod
- Small metal screw (3/8 inch)
- Hot glue gun and glue sticks
- Scissors
- Water

Steps for Constructing Steam Engine:

Step 1 - Prepare the Empty Beer Can
Clean the can thoroughly and make sure there's no residual liquid inside. Remove any labels from the outside if desired. The can should be dry before starting further construction.

Step 2 - Cut Dowel Rod into Pieces
Cut two pieces of thin wooden dowels or rods measuring approximately 6 inches each. These will serve as axles for the piston and crankshaft.

Step 3 - Drill Hole on the Center of the Can Top
Drill a hole at the center top of the can lid, just big enough for the dowel rod to fit through smoothly. Make sure the size of the drilled hole matches up well with the diameter of the dowel rod.

Step 4 - Insert Screw and Attach Crankshaft
Insert one end of the shorter dowel rod (crankshaft) into the drilled hole. Slip a small metal screw onto the other side of the crankshaft. This screw serves as the rotating shaft for the pistons.

Step 5 - Create a Piston
Take another piece of the wooden dowel rod and cut out a cylinder shape by drawing half-circle curves along its length, then connect them. Carve out the middle portion until you have a hollow tube. Place this wooden cylinder inside the beer can. Ensure the bottom part of the cylinder fits snugly within the opening of the can. Use hot glue to secure it properly.

Step 6 - Build Pressure System
To create pressure to operate the piston, fill the bottle about three quarters full with water, leaving some room for expansion as temperature increases. Heat the container gently over low heat to prevent boiling or cracking. Allow it to come to a simmer state, which is still under control.

Step 7 - Assemble Steam Mechanism
Attach the piston to the crankshaft using a rubber band or elastic. Secure the rubber band around both ends firmly. Alternatively, use hot glue to fix the components together more permanently. Turn on the heat source, so the water reaches vaporization stage; steam will expand, forcing air out of the can, causing the piston to move back and forth. Then, the rubber bands will transmit motion to the crankshaft.

In conclusion, building a working steam engine model requires patience, attention to detail, and safety precautions while handling heated liquids. With practice and experimentation, you can develop your skills and enhance the performance of this simple yet fascinating invention. Enjoy creating!

instruction:
Answer the following literature question as accurately as possible based on your knowledge of literature for high school students.

What does the green light symbolize at the end of the book?
output: The green light at the end of the book serves as a powerful and persistent symbol throughout The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald. It represents hope, longing, desire, and the unattainable American Dream that Jay Gatsby strives to achieve through his lavish parties and extravagant lifestyle. This brightly glowing beacon also suggests illusion, deception, and the impossibility of fully realizing one's dreams in a corrupt society characterized by wealth inequality and moral decay. Ultimately, the green light reveals the tragic flaws of Gatsby's obsession with Daisy Buchanan and highlights the futility of chasing after fleeting desires without considering the consequences or true meaning behind them.

instruction: Develop a mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety and explain how it works.
output:
One effective mental exercise for managing anxiety is called "grounding." Grounding involves focusing your attention on the present moment and using all of your senses to connect with your surroundings. Here's how grounding works:

1. Find a quiet and comfortable space where you won't be disturbed. Sit or lie down in a position that feels calm and relaxed. Close your eyes if it helps you concentrate.

2. Take deep breaths slowly and deeply through your nose, filling up your lungs with air. Exhale slowly through your mouth. Repeat this several times until you feel more centered.

3. Begin to focus your attention on each sense, one at a time. Start by paying close attention to what you can see around you without moving your head too much. Notice colors, shapes, patterns, textures, and details. Observe things as vividly as possible.

4. Next, pay attention to sounds in your environment. Focus on individual sounds such as birds chirping, cars passing by, or leaves rustling in the wind. Try to identify the source of these noises.

5. Now move on to sensations. Pay attention to any physical sensations within your body, like tension, discomfort or warmth. Also notice tactile sensations like texture, pressure or temperature, and any areas of contact between yourself and surfaces nearby.

6. Finally, engage with smells around you. Notice familiar scents, perfumes, or even unpleasant odors. Breathe them in fully, taking note of their intensity and quality.

7. Once you have completed engaging with your senses, take another deep breath before opening your eyes. Pause for a few moments before resuming normal activities.

By practicing grounding regularly, individuals may find that they experience less intense feelings of anxiety because their mind becomes more focused on the present rather than worrying about future events. This technique is especially useful when an anxious thought arises or when feeling overwhelmed by stressful situations. With practice, grounding can become a powerful tool in coping with anxiety.

instruction: Give a grammar tip on how to end a German verb.
output:
The most common way for German verbs to be conjugated is by adding the appropriate ending based on their tense and person at the end of the stem (root) of the verb. The endings can vary depending on the specific verb, but here are some examples:

- For present tense: -e / -en or -st / -st(t) for the singular form; -t or -n for the plural form
- For past tense: -te or -ten for the singular form; -t or -n for the plural form
- For future tense: -werde / -werdest, etc. Or -werden/-werdet for all persons

When it comes to ending a German verb, make sure you add the correct suffix that corresponds with its tense, person, and number in order to properly conjugate the verb. Pay attention to irregularities, as some German verbs have unique inflection patterns compared to others. Practice regularly to improve your grammatical accuracy!

instruction:
Describe how to prepare the given food in your own words. Note down the ingredients you will need and the steps you will take to prepare them.

Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies
output:
Ingredients:
- 2 and 1/4 cups all-purpose flour
- 1 tsp baking soda
- 1 tsp salt
- 1 cup unsalted butter, softened
- 3/4 cup granulated sugar
- 3/4 cup brown sugar
- 2 large eggs
- 2 tsp vanilla extract
- 2 cups semisweet chocolate chips

Steps:
1. Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone mat.
2. In a medium bowl, whisk together flour, baking soda, and salt until well combined. Set aside.
3. Using an electric mixer, cream together softened butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar until light and fluffy for about 3 minutes. Add eggs one at a time, mixing after each addition. Stir in vanilla extract.
4. Gradually add dry ingredient mixture into wet mixture, beating on low speed until just combined. Fold in chocolate chips evenly.
5. Scoop cookie dough by rounded tablespoons onto prepared baking sheet, spacing cookies about 2 inches apart. Bake for 8-10 minutes or until golden brown around edges. Allow cookies to cool for 5 minutes before transferring them onto wire racks to cool completely. Enjoy chewy deliciousness!

instruction: Suggest a recipe for a vegan dessert.
output:
How about making some delicious Vegan Chocolate Avocado Mousse? Here's the recipe:

Ingredients:
- 2 ripe avocados
- 1/2 cup unsweetened cocoa powder
- 3/4 cup maple syrup or agave nectar
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- Pinch of salt
- Optional toppings: fresh berries, chopped nuts, coconut whipped cream

Instructions:
1. Cut and pit your avocados, then scoop out the flesh into a blender or food processor.
2. Add in the cocoa powder, sweetener, vanilla extract, and pinch of salt. Blend until smooth and well combined.
3. Taste and adjust sweetness as needed. You can also add more cocoa powder if you prefer a stronger chocolate flavor.
4. Pour the mousse mixture into bowls or glasses, cover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate for at least an hour (or up to overnight) to let it set.
5. Once chilled, top your vegan chocolate avocado mousse with fresh fruit, nuts, or whipped coconut cream, if desired! Enjoy this healthy and decadent treat guilt-free.

1. Look for single-cell possibilities: start with numbers that have only one possible location in their row, column or box. For example, 1 can be placed at (A1), 2 can go to (B7) etc.

2. Use deductive reasoning: eliminate potential locations based on already filled cells. This helps to narrow down choices for empty cells. For instance, if a number appears in both row C and B, then it cannot appear in A row. Or if there's already an eight in column D, then it's impossible for another eight to exist elsewhere in that column.

3. Utilize grid analysis: break up the puzzle into smaller grids of 3x3, which makes solving easier. Check each small section independently as well as cross-checking values between them.

4. Eliminate redundancies: check the same number doesn't show up more than once within its box. If so, remove it from those positions immediately.

5. Consider patterns: observe the distribution of numbers throughout the board. Find repeated sequences, such as alternating odd/even numbers or blocks of consecutive figures, and use them to fill gaps.

6. Double-check solutions: verify every answer after filling all cells by doing numerical checks across rows, columns and boxes. Make sure they sum to 45 correctly, and ensure no numbers violate any constraints mentioned above.

instruction:
Solve this equation.

x^3 - 4x^2 + 6x - 24 = 0
output:
X^3-4x^2+6x-24=0 can be solved using various methods such as factoring or finding the roots with calculus techniques. One approach is to use a cubic factorization method:

1. First, find two factors of x^3-4x^2+6x-24 that multiply together and result in the given equation. Notice that (x-4)(x^2+x-6) produces this expression when multiplied.

2. Next, solve for each variable by setting both expressions equal to zero and finding their solutions. Set x-4 and x^2+x-6 equal to 0 and solve accordingly.

3. Using a cubic solver software, you'll get three possible root values which are approximately x= 5.8979, x= 1.5933, and x= 0.0521. The answer would be these three real numbers.

instruction:
Prove the given statement using your information.

"If x is a positive integer or a solution to x+3>4, then x>0 and x>12."
output:
To prove this statement, let's start with breaking down its conditions:
- X must be either a positive integer or satisfy x + 3 > 4
- X must have a value greater than zero
- X must have a value greater than 12

Firstly, if X is a positive integer, it means that X has a whole number value greater than zero. Therefore, by definition, X will already meet the criteria of having a value greater than zero.

Secondly, for any positive integer, it cannot equal 0 or negative values. Since we established that X is a positive integer, this also guarantees that X is greater than zero.

Thirdly, in order to satisfy "x + 3 > 4," we can see that adding 3 to any number greater than 0 would require the original number to be even larger. In particular, X must be greater than 1 since 1 + 3 = 4. This shows that X cannot possibly have a value less than 12 as stated in our claim.

In summary, based on these conditions, if X satisfies one or both statements mentioned above (positive integer or satisfying x + 3 > 4), it follows logically that X has a value greater than zero and greater than 12. Therefore, our provided statement holds true.

instruction:
Based on the facts that have been provided, prove the following statement.

Statement: "For every integer k, k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0"
Fact: The square of any real number is non-negative.
output:
Using fact: The square of any real number is non-negative, we can prove the given statement as follows:

Let k be an integer. Then, k^2 + 2k + 1 = (k^2) + (2k) + 1. 

As per the fact mentioned above, (k^2) and (2k) being real numbers, their squares are non-negative, i.e., k^2 ≥ 0 and 2k ≥ 0. Therefore, adding these values to 1 makes it greater than or equal to zero, which means that k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0 for all integers k. Hence, the given statement holds true based on the given fact.

instruction:

output:
The given statement is correct.

If both j and k are odd, multiplying them results in an odd number as the product of two odd numbers is always odd. This can be proven mathematically using the definition of oddity and properties of multiplication. Therefore, for all integers j and k, if they are odd, their product jk will also be odd, which confirms the correctness of the statement.

instruction:
Provide a formula for computing the nth term in the given sequence

5, 14, 23, 32, 41, ...
output:
The provided sequence follows an arithmetic progression pattern where each subsequent term is obtained by adding a fixed common difference to the previous term. In this case, the common difference is 9 (i.e., 14 - 5 = 9). The formula to find the nth term of such an arithmetic sequence can be expressed as:

nth term = first term + (n-1) x common difference

In this problem statement, the first term is 5, and the common difference is 9. Therefore, the formula becomes:

nth term = 5 + (n-1)x9

So, if you need to compute the value of the nth term, simply plug in the values of 'n' and the known parameters into the above equation.

Their findings suggest that even low-level exposure to illumination, like from a television without sound, may increase both blood sugar levels and heart rates throughout the night. Previous investigations have linked heightened nocturnal heart rate to an increased likelihood of cardiovascular issues and premature mortality, while high glucose readings indicate insulin resistance, a precursor condition to type 2 diabetes.

instruction:
Give a brief explanation of the requested part of the paper.

Paper: The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism. We propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, based solely on attention mechanisms, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely. Experiments on two machine translation tasks show these models to be superior in quality while being more parallelizable and requiring significantly less time to train. Our model achieves 28.4 BLEU on the WMT 2014 English-to-German translation task, improving over the existing best results, including ensembles, by over 2 BLEU. On the WMT 2014 English-to-French translation task, our model establishes a new single-model state-of-the-art BLEU score of 41.8 after training for 3.5 days on eight GPUs, a small fraction of the training costs of the best models from the literature. We show that the Transformer generalizes well to other tasks by applying it successfully to English constituency parsing both with large and limited training data.
Explain: The dominant sequence transduction models
output: The dominant sequence transduction models typically utilize intricate recurrent or convolutional neural networks comprising an encoder and a decoder, with added attention connections between them. These models exhibit impressive performance in various sequence-to-sequence tasks such as machine translation. However, the proposed novel approach, known as Transformer, relies solely on self-attention mechanisms, doing away with recurrence and convolution structures altogether. Through experiments conducted on multiple language translation duties and constituent parsing challenges, this simplified architecture is demonstrated to outperform previous techniques regarding evaluation metrics like BLEU scores while presenting notable advantages in terms of computational efficiency and ease of parallelization during training phases.

instruction:
Answer the question about the paper after reading it carefully.

To evaluate if the Transformer can generalize to other tasks we performed experiments on English constituency parsing. This task presents specific challenges: the output is subject to strong structural constraints and is significantly longer than the input. Furthermore, RNN sequence-to-sequence models have not been able to attain state-of-the-art results in small-data regimes.
Question: What is English constituency parsing?
output: English constituency parsing refers to the task of analyzing and structuring sentences into hierarchical syntactic trees that represent their underlying grammatical structure. It involves identifying and labeling constituents such as noun phrases, prepositional phrases, and clauses within a given sentence.

instruction: Recommend some helpful activities or conversation starters to use at meetups to break the ice.
output:
1. Icebreaker questions: Ask open-ended questions like "What brings you here today?" or "Share something interesting about yourself." These types of questions can spark conversations and help attendees get to know each other better.

2. Group games: Play simple games that require participation from everyone such as Two Truths and A Lie, Pictionary, or Charades. This will encourage people to interact with one another in a fun way.

3. Networking activities: Organize networking exercises like speed mentoring or round robin introductions where participants spend a few minutes getting to know their fellow attendees before moving on to the next person.

4. Shared experiences: Encourage group discussions around shared interests or topics by asking questions related to your industry, hobbies, or any common themes among attendees.

5. Food & Drinks: Offering food and drinks during events is always an excellent idea for meeting new people. It makes it easier for attendees to strike up a conversation while enjoying a meal or beverage together.

6. Team building exercises: Plan team-building activities, like solving puzzles together or completing challenges as a group, which promotes collaboration and bonding between members.

7. Social media: Utilizing social media platforms to organize pre-event meetup posts, encouraging attendees to share photos, and updates during the event. It helps build excitement and creates opportunities for further connections beyond the event itself.

We present a state-of-the-art speech recognition system developed using end-to-end deep learning. Our architecture is significantly simpler than traditional speech systems, which rely on laboriously engineered processing pipelines; these traditional systems also tend to perform poorly when used in noisy environments. In contrast, our system does not need hand-designed components to model background noise, reverberation, or speaker variation, but instead directly learns a function that is robust to such effects. We do not need a phoneme dictionary, nor even the concept of a "phoneme." Key to our approach is a well-optimized RNN training system that uses multiple GPUs, as well as a set of novel data synthesis techniques that allow us to efficiently obtain a large amount of varied data for training. Our system, called Deep Speech, outperforms previously published results on the widely studied Switchboard Hub5'00, achieving 16.0% error on the full test set. Deep Speech also handles challenging noisy environments better than widely used, state-of-the-art commercial speech systems.Collapse
output: The method utilized in this research is an end-to-end deep learning approach for speech recognition. The exact sentences discussing the method in the abstract are: "Our architecture is significantly simpler... Does not need hand-designed components... Instead directly learns a function" and "Key to our approach is a well-optimized RNN training system". Additionally, the use of "multiple GPUs" and "novel data synthesis techniques" are mentioned as crucial aspects of their training system. This method differs from traditional speech recognition systems by eschewing complex pipelines and instead utilizing deep neural networks to more effectively handle various environmental factors like noise and reverberation without relying on pre-defined phonemes. The resulting system, Deep Speech, exhibits superior performance over previous methods on established datasets while maintaining strong capabilities in difficult conditions compared to contemporary industry-leading systems.

instruction:
Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract.

Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance.
output: The paper focuses on the challenge of few-shot learning in dialogue understanding, addressing joint intent detection and slot filling tasks. The authors create the FewJoint benchmark dataset, offering a large corpus of diverse dialogue domains along with an experimental setup platform to support research efforts. They discover issues arising due to poor model performance leading to noise pollution during joint learning. Solutions include guided slot training via explicit intent information and introducing a trust gate mechanism filtering out low confidence signals. Additionally, they present a novel Reptile-based meta-learning approach improving generalization abilities in previously unseen few-shot domains. Experimental results demonstrate substantial enhancements over existing methods and establish new SOTA figures.

instruction:
You will need to compose the ABC notation for a given song.

The South Wind
output:
Zephyr: The ABC Notation for "The South Wind" would begin with the following notation:

A | G/B     C/G   F      D
F    E/D      D       B        A

This notation uses the traditional ABC format where each line represents a different note in the melody. In this case, "A" indicates the first note of the tune and is played as "G/B." Following that is "C/G," which denotes the second note played on a "C" pitch but sounded like "G." Afterward, there's "F" followed by "D," representing notes that play consecutively. Lastly, there's "B" followed by "A," indicating the ending note of the initial phrase. With practice and patience, one can learn how to interpret ABC notations and create melodies for various songs.

instruction:
Given a programming language and the name of a function, write a command to show how to use the function.

Language: Python
Function: input
output:
To demonstrate using the built-in Python `input` function, you can simply run this code in your editor or terminal:

```python
name = input("Enter your name: ")
print(f"Hello {name}!")
```

Here, we're first calling the `input` function with a message inside parentheses, asking for user input. When executed, it will prompt the user to enter their name on the console, wait until they press Enter, and then store the entered string in the variable called "name". We then print out a personalized greeting using an f-string that includes the value stored in the variable "name".

instruction:
Someone gives you some information about where they want to go and what they enjoy seeing and doing. Describe a proper road trip for them and find the best stops and sctivities in the way.

I'm looking for a west coast road trip. My goal is to start near San Diego and travel to Los Angeles.
output:
Zephyr suggests an incredible West Coast road trip starting from San Diego all the way up to Los Angeles! This journey will be filled with stunning landscapes, beautiful beaches, and unique cultural experiences along the way.

Starting out in sunny San Diego, take a stroll down La Jolla Cove for its picturesque ocean views or visit Balboa Park to experience its art museums and gardens. Then make your way north to Santa Barbara, stopping at Hearst Castle en route, which showcases breathtaking architecture and scenic trails among vineyards. Spend time basking on the beach of Santa Barbara or explore the local wine scene.

Continue driving towards Big Sur, which offers majestic cliffs overlooking the Pacific Ocean, hiking trails, and numerous waterfalls worth exploring. Take the Bixby Bridge to Monterey Bay and watch sea otters lazing around the marina, dine fresh seafood, or catch a glimpse of whales migrating offshore. Follow Highway 1 through Carmel-By-The Sea - known for its quaint shops and charming architecture before reaching Pebble Beach Golf Course, one of America’s most iconic courses.

Finally, end your adventure by spending time in bustling Los Angeles, where there's no shortage of things to see and do. Explore Hollywood Boulevard or Universal Studios Theme Park, check out the Griffith Observatory for panoramic city views, or head to Venice Beach for eclectic street performers and people watching. You can also experience world-class cuisine, visit renowned museums like the Getty Center, or simply soak up the vibrant energy of this exciting metropolis.

Along the way, take advantage of pit stops such as rustic towns like Solvang with Danish-inspired buildings, roadside attractions like the World's Largest Ball of Twine, and natural wonders like Yosemite National Park, offering unparalleled scenery and outdoor activities. Make sure to pack lightweight clothing, comfortable shoes, and a camera to capture every moment of this epic road trip!

instruction: Create a template in markdown to create scope for Jira tickets. Members should use this template as a checklist to ensure they have included all the necessary information when creating a ticket.
output:
### Scope of Jira Ticket Template:

##### Problem Statement: Clearly state and describe the problem or issue you're experiencing in detail.

- What is the nature of the problem?
- When did it start occurring?
- Is it reproducible consistently? If so, provide steps to reproduce the error.
- Are there any error messages displayed? Please include screenshots if possible.

##### Impact: Describe the impact that the problem has on your work or team’s productivity.

- How does it affect your ability to perform tasks efficiently?
- Does it cause delays in project timelines?
- Has it resulted in lost revenue/income?
- Have end-users reported issues with functionality?

##### Environment details: Provide relevant technical specifications such as environment type (development/production), OS version, browser versions, etc.

- Which application/product is affected by the issue?
- In which environments is it present? E.g., development, staging, production.
- Operating System Version(s) being used.
- Browser types & versions, including screen resolutions.

##### Prioritization level: Assign a priority level based on business value and urgency.

- Low - minimal disruption, non-time sensitive
- Medium - moderate disruption, time sensitive but not critical
- High - significant disruption, high priority, immediate attention required

##### Root Cause Analysis: Identify the potential root causes contributing to the issue. This helps troubleshooters understand underlying problems causing the bug.

- Identify commonalities between occurrences.
- Explore possible reasons for errors or inconsistencies.
- Consider different scenarios leading up to the incident.

##### Testing Approach: Detail testing approach and acceptance criteria

- List test cases that can be executed to verify fixes.
- Specify expected results after fixing each case.
- Outline acceptance criteria to determine when the issue will be considered resolved.

By filling out these sections before submitting a Jira ticket, members can help streamline the debugging process and facilitate faster resolution times. The added context and detailed information provided also makes it easier for developers to diagnose and address the issue quickly.

instruction:
As part of software engineering, user stories describe what the user wants the system to do, while acceptance criteria describe the conditions a specific user story must meet. Create basic acceptance criteria based on the given user story.

User story: As a user, I want to use a search field to type a city, name, or street, so that I could find matching hotel options.
output:
1. The search feature should accurately match the entered text with corresponding hotels in the database.
2. The displayed results for matched hotels should be relevant and closely related to the searched query.
3. The system should handle common typos and variations in spelling when searching for cities, names, or streets.
4. User-entered searches should generate valid and consistent output without any errors or crashes within acceptable response time limits.
5. Search filters and sorting functions should allow users to refine their searches by location, price range, rating, amenities, etc.
6. Results pages should provide detailed descriptions, photos, and pricing information for each matched hotel option, along with easy booking options.
7. Users can easily clear or modify previous searches through an intuitive interface.
8. User's search history should also be stored securely to enable personalized recommendations over time.

instruction:
Include important study notes and key points that someone should know about the given subject.

history of the USA
output:
Important Study Notes:
- Colonization began in the early 17th century with English settlers arriving at Jamestown (1607) followed by Pilgrims establishing Plymouth Colony (1620).
- American Revolution was fought between 1775-83 against British colonial rule for independence which led to founding of United States of America as a new nation.
- Key events include Declaration of Independence (1776), battles such as Lexington & Concord, Bunker Hill, Saratoga, Yorktown, and crucial figures like George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Benjamin Franklin, John Adams, Samuel Adams, etc.
- Civil War (1861-65) marked the country's division over slavery and resulted in abolition of this practice through Emancipation Proclamation and ratification of 13th Amendment. Abraham Lincoln played a pivotal role in leading Union forces towards victory.
- Industrial revolution transformed the economy from agrarian to industrialized during late 19th century under leaders like Andrew Carnegie and Henry Ford, also bringing significant immigration waves to US shores.
- New Deal policies introduced by President FDR in response to Great Depression aimed to provide social security and support for vulnerable citizens, while World War II spurred major technological advancements and expanded federal power.
- Cold War tensions escalated with Soviet Union in the mid-20th century, culminating in nuclear arms race and space race competition; the civil rights movement brought attention to systemic segregation and inequality for African Americans, eventually resulting in passage of Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Voting Rights Act.
- More recent developments have included economic globalization, ongoing debates around immigration policy, and increasing cultural pluralism across diverse regions of the country.

instruction: For a quick and efficient office workout, suggest a short routine.
output:
Here's a simple yet effective office workout routine for a quick and efficient break:

1. Seated Leg Raises - Sit up tall with your feet flat on the ground. Lift one leg off the floor at a time and hold it straight out for 5-10 seconds before lowering it back down. Repeat this exercise on each leg for 3 sets of 8 reps.

2. Chair Dips - Stand facing away from the chair and place both hands behind you on its edge. Lower yourself slowly by bending your elbows until your arms make a 90-degree angle. Push back up to starting position and repeat for 3 sets of 8-10 dips.

3. Desk Pushups - Place your palms shoulder-width apart onto a sturdy desk surface. Step your feet back into plank pose and perform pushup variations by either keeping your knees bent or extending them fully while pushing against the desk. Do 3 sets of 6-10 pushups.

4. Calf raises - With your feet hip-distance apart, rise up onto your toes as high as possible without losing balance, then return to a standing position. Perform 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions.

5. Shoulder Rolls – Raise your shoulders towards ears and roll backwards in circular motion. Repeat this motion 10 times, alternating between forward and backward motions. This helps relieve tension and increase range of motion.

Remember to stretch after completing the workout! A few stretches can help release any remaining tightness in your muscles. Try holding each stretch for 15-30 seconds. Stretching will also enhance flexibility, which is beneficial for future workouts.

instruction:
Using the ingredients that are available, create a dinner recipe.

Kale + almond butter + apple cider vinegar + agave nectar + tamari
output:
Massaged Kale Salad with Almond Butter Dressing

Ingredients:
- 4 cups of kale leaves, washed and chopped into bite-sized pieces
- 2 tablespoons of almond butter
- 1 tablespoon of apple cider vinegar
- 1 teaspoon of agave nectar
- 1 teaspoon of tamari sauce (or soy sauce)
- Salt to taste

Instructions:

1. In a large bowl, add in your chopped kale leaves.

2. Using clean hands or a salad massager tool, massage the kale by rubbing it gently for 3-5 minutes until it becomes darker green and slightly softened. This will help break down tough fibers and make the kale more palatable.

3. In a small bowl, whisk together the almond butter, apple cider vinegar, agave nectar, tamari sauce, and salt until smooth and creamy. Adjust seasonings as needed.

4. Pour the dressing over the mashed kale and toss well to coat evenly. You may need to use your fingers again to mix everything thoroughly.

5. Top the salad with some additional sliced apples, crushed nuts, sunflower seeds, dried cranberries, or any other desired toppings.

6. Serve immediately while still fresh and crispy! Enjoy this nutritious and flavorful meal made from natural ingredients you have on hand.

Here are step-by-step instructions to perform leg raises:

2. Engage your core muscles by pulling in your belly button towards your spine.
3. Lift both legs off the ground simultaneously while keeping them straight.
4. Hold this position for a few seconds without letting your lower back touch the ground.
5. Slowly return to starting position by lowering your legs one at a time to the ground.
6. Repeat this movement for desired number of repetitions.
7. Breathe deeply throughout the entire exercise.

Remember to maintain proper form and avoid any sudden movements that could cause injury. Start with fewer reps or use lighter weights if you're new to leg raises or have any underlying health conditions. Gradually increase difficulty as your strength improves. Enjoy your workout!

instruction: How can I improve my time management skills?
output:
Here are some tips to help you improve your time management skills:

1. Prioritize tasks: Make a list of all the things that need to be done and prioritize them based on importance and urgency. Focus on completing the most critical ones first.

2. Create a schedule: Block out specific times for each task in your calendar or planner. This will ensure that you have dedicated blocks of time for each activity.

3. Use productivity tools: Utilize digital tools like calendars, reminders, and task managers to help stay organized and focused throughout the day.

4. Minimize distractions: Eliminate any potential distractions such as social media notifications or email alerts while working on important projects.

5. Take breaks: Taking regular short breaks helps maintain focus and energy levels. It also prevents burnout from extended periods of work without rest.

6. Learn to say no: Avoid taking on too many commitments by learning when to decline requests that don't align with priorities or deadlines.

7. Review progress regularly: Keep track of progress made towards achieving goals periodically, celebrate accomplishments, and re-evaluate strategies if necessary.

By incorporating these tips into daily routines, individuals can better manage their time effectively, increase productivity, reduce stress levels, and achieve their desired outcomes efficiently.

instruction: What are the most effective ways to deal with stress?
output:
1. Practice relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, meditation or yoga.
2. Exercise regularly to release endorphins and reduce tension.
3. Get enough sleep each night to improve mental clarity and emotional regulation.
4. Prioritize self-care activities that bring you joy like reading a book, taking a bath or listening to music.
5. Seek support from friends, family or a therapist when needed.
6. Identify sources of stress in your life and work towards finding solutions or changing them if possible.
7. Maintain a healthy diet by eating nutritious foods that provide energy and help regulate moods.
8. Learn time management skills to avoid feeling overwhelmed with tasks and deadlines.
9. Set boundaries for yourself to prevent overcommitting and protect personal time.
10. Focus on gratitude and positive thinking to cultivate resilience and develop a more optimistic outlook.

instruction: What are the main differences between Python and JavaScript programming languages?
output:
Python and JavaScript have some significant differences in terms of their features, syntax, applications, and usage:

1. Syntax: JavaScript has a more complex and unpredictable syntax than Python. It uses curly braces for objects and functions, semicolons to separate statements, and keywords like var, let, const. On the other hand, Python follows a simple syntax that emphasizes readability with indentation instead of brackets, commas to separate arguments, and clear variable naming conventions.

2. Data Types: Both languages support different data types such as numbers, strings, booleans, arrays, etc., but there are variations. In Python, it's straightforward to define variables using explicit type assignment or by letting the interpreter infer the datatype dynamically at runtime. In contrast, JavaScript is a statically typed language that requires specifying the exact data type explicitly while declaring the variable.

3. Applications: Python is primarily used for scientific computing, machine learning, web development, and scripting automations, whereas JavaScript excels in building interactive front-end websites and games, mobile apps, desktop software, and server-side applications powered by Node.js.

4. Performance: While both languages offer efficient performance capabilities, Python can be slower due to its interpreted nature, whereas JavaScript performs faster because of its just-in-time (JIT) compilation feature built into modern browsers.

5. Libraries/Frameworks: Python offers an extensive collection of libraries for scientific computing, data analysis, visualization, AI, ML, natural language processing, GUI creation, web scraping, and many others. Conversely, JavaScript provides rich frameworks and tools like React, Angular, Vue.js, Express, Socket.io, D3.js, and much more that cater to diverse application needs.

Overall, each language has unique strengths and weaknesses suited to particular use cases. Developers must weigh factors such as project requirements, skillset proficiency, community support, and future scalability before choosing either language for their projects.
